member.summary: The AVIMAINHEADER structure defines global information in an AVI file.

member.summary: Specifies the number of microseconds between frames. This value indicates the overall timing for the file.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviMainHeader.MaxBytesPerSec
member.summary: Specifies the approximate maximum data rate of the file. This value indicates the number of bytes per second the system must handle to present an AVI sequence as specified by the other parameters contained in the main header and stream header chunks.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviMainHeader.PaddingGranularity
member.summary: Specifies the alignment for data, in bytes. Pad the data to multiples of this value.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviMainHeader.Flags
member.summary: Contains a bitwise combination of zero or more of the .

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviMainHeader.TotalFrames
member.summary: Specifies the total number of frames of data in the file.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviMainHeader.InitialFrames
member.summary: Specifies the initial frame for interleaved files. Noninterleaved files should specify zero. If you are creating interleaved files, specify the number of frames in the file prior to the initial frame of the AVI sequence in this member. To give the audio driver enough audio to work with, the audio data in an interleaved file must be skewed from the video data.Typically, the audio data should be moved forward enough frames to allow approximately 0.75 seconds of audio data to be preloaded.The dwInitialRecords member should be set to the number of frames the audio is skewed.Also set the same value for the dwInitialFrames member of the AVISTREAMHEADER structure in the audio stream header.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviMainHeader.Streams
member.summary: Specifies the number of streams in the file. For example, a file with audio and video has two streams.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviMainHeader.SuggestedBufferSize
member.summary: Specifies the suggested buffer size for reading the file. Generally, this size should be large enough to contain the largest chunk in the file. If set to zero, or if it is too small, the playback software will have to reallocate memory during playback, which will reduce performance. For an interleaved file, the buffer size should be large enough to read an entire record, and not just a chunk.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviMainHeader.Width
member.summary: Specifies the width of the AVI file in pixels.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviMainHeader.Height
member.summary: Specifies the height of the AVI file in pixels.

member.name: T:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader
member.summary: The structure contains information about one stream in an AVI file.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.Type
member.summary: Contains a that specifies the type of the data contained in the stream.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.Handler
member.summary: Optionally, contains a that identifies a specific data handler. The data handler is the preferred handler for the stream. For audio and video streams, this specifies the codec for decoding the stream.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.Flags
member.summary: Contains any flags for the data stream. The bits in the high-order word of these flags are specific to the type of data contained in the stream.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.Priority
member.summary: Specifies priority of a stream type. For example, in a file with multiple audio streams, the one with the highest priority might be the default stream.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.Language
member.summary: Language tag.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.InitialFrames
member.summary: Specifies how far audio data is skewed ahead of the video frames in interleaved files. Typically, this is about 0.75 seconds. If you are creating interleaved files, specify the number of frames in the file prior to the initial frame of the AVI sequence in this member. For more information, see the remarks for the dwInitialFrames member of the structure.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.Scale
member.summary: Used with to specify the time scale that this stream will use. Dividing by gives the number of samples per second. For video streams, this is the frame rate. For audio streams, this rate corresponds to the time needed to play nBlockAlign bytes of audio, which for PCM audio is the just the sample rate.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.Rate
member.summary: See .

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.Start
member.summary: Specifies the starting time for this stream. The units are defined by the and members in the main file header. Usually, this is zero, but it can specify a delay time for a stream that does not start concurrently with the file.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.Length
member.summary: Specifies the length of this stream. The units are defined by the and members of the stream's header.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.SuggestedBufferSize
member.summary: Specifies how large a buffer should be used to read this stream. Typically, this contains a value corresponding to the largest chunk present in the stream. Using the correct buffer size makes playback more efficient. Use zero if you do not know the correct buffer size.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.Quality
member.summary: Specifies an indicator of the quality of the data in the stream. Quality is represented as a number between 0 and 10,000. For compressed data, this typically represents the value of the quality parameter passed to the compression software. If set to â€“1, drivers use the default quality value.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.SampleSize
member.summary: Specifies the size of a single sample of data. This is set to zero if the samples can vary in size. If this number is nonzero, then multiple samples of data can be grouped into a single chunk within the file. If it is zero, each sample of data (such as a video frame) must be in a separate chunk. For video streams, this number is typically zero, although it can be nonzero if all video frames are the same size. For audio streams, this number should be the same as the nBlockAlign member of the WAVEFORMATEX structure describing the audio.

member.summary: Gets the upper-left corner for the video stream.

member.summary: Gets the upper-left corner for the video stream.

member.summary: Gets the lower-right corner of the video stream.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.AviStreamHeader.Bottom
member.summary: Gets the lower-right corner of the video stream.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.VMware.BitmapInfoHeader.ClrImportant
member.summary: Specifies the number of color indices that are considered important for displaying the bitmap. If this value is zero, all colors are important.

member.summary: Gets the X11 keysym of the key. For many keys this is the ASCII value.

member.name: P:RemoteViewing.Vnc.KeyChangedEventArgs.Pressed
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a key was pressed.
member.value: true for a key press event, or false for a key release event.

summary.para: keysym codes are 29-bit integer values identify characters or functions associated with each key (e.g., via the visible engraving) of a keyboard layout.
For most ordinary keys, the keysym is the same as the corresponding ASCII value.
Modern versions of the X Window System handle keysyms for Unicode characters, consisting of the Unicode character with the hex 1000000 bit set.

The Y coordinate of the mouse.
A bit mask of pressed mouse buttons, in X11 convention: 1 is left, 2 is middle, and 4 is right. Mouse wheel scrolling is treated as a button event: 8 for up and 16 for down.

members.member:
Represents the raw VNC encoding protocol.
The simplest encoding type is raw pixel data. In this case the data consists of width * height pixel values (where width and height are the width and height of the rectangle). The values simply represent each pixel in left-to-right scanline order.
.

member.name: T:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding
member.summary: Defines the encoding format used by the client and the server.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.Raw
member.summary: The data is encoded in the raw encoding format.
member.remarks: In this case the data consists of width Ã— height pixel values (where width and height are the width and height of the rectangle). The values simply represent each pixel in left-to-right scanline order

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.CopyRect
member.summary: The CopyRect (copy rectangle) encoding is a very simple and efficient encoding which can be used when the client already has the same pixel data elsewhere in its framebuffer. The encoding on the wire simply consists of an X,Y coordinate. This gives a position in the framebuffer from which the client can copy the rectangle of pixel data.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.RRE
member.summary: RRE stands for rise-and-run-length encoding and as its name implies, it is essentially a two-dimensional analogue of run-length encoding. RRE-encoded rectangles arrive at the client in a form which can be rendered immediately and efficiently by the simplest of graphics engines. RRE is not appropriate for complex desktops, but can be useful in some situations.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.CoRRE
member.summary: CoRRE stands for compressed rise-and-run-length encoding and as its name implies, it is a variant of the above RRE Encoding and as such essentially a two-dimensional analogue of run-length encoding.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.Hextile
member.summary: Rectangles are split up into 16x16 tiles, allowing the dimensions of the subrectangles to be specified in 4 bits each, 16 bits in total. The rectangle is split into tiles starting at the top left going in left-to-right, topto-bottom order. The encoded contents of the tiles simply follow one another in the predetermined order.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.Zlib
member.summary: Combines zlib compression, tiling, palettisation and run-length encoding. On the wire, the rectangle begins with a 4-byte length field, and is followed by that many bytes of zlib-compressed data.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.Tight
member.summary: Tight encoding provides efficient compression for pixel data. To reduce implementation complexity, the width of any Tight-encoded rectangle cannot exceed 2048 pixels. If a wider rectangle is desired, it must be split into several rectangles and each one should be encoded separately.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.ZlibHex
member.summary: The zlibhex encoding uses zlib [3] to optionally compress subrectangles according to the Hextile Encoding.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.TRLE
member.summary: TRLE stands for Tiled Run-Length Encoding, and combines tiling, palettization, and run-length encoding.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.Zrle
member.summary: ZRLE stands for Zlib [3] Run-Length Encoding, and combines zlib compression, tiling, palettisation and run-length encoding. On the wire, the rectangle begins with a 4-byte length field, and is followed by that many bytes of zlib-compressed data.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.Jpeg
member.summary: JPEG encoding.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.JRLE
member.summary: A hybrid of lossy and lossless encodings, in particular JPEG and a variation of RLE (Run Length Encoding).

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.TightPng
member.summary: The Tight PNG encoding is a variant of the encoding that disallows the BasicCompression type and replaces it with a new PngCompression type.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.Fence
member.summary: A client which requests the pseudo-encoding is declaring that it supports and/or wishes to use the Fence extension.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.ContinuousUpdates
member.summary: A client which requests the pseudo-encoding is declaring that it wishes to use the EnableContinuousUpdates extension.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.CursorWithAlpha
member.summary: A client which requests the psuedo-encoding is declaring that it wishes to use the CursorWithAlpha extension.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.PseudoCursor
member.summary: A client which requests the pseudo-encoding is declaring that it is capable of drawing a mouse cursor locally. This can significantly improve perceived performance over slow links

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.PseudoDesktopSize
member.summary: A client which requests the pseudo-encoding is declaring that it is capable of coping with a change in the framebuffer width and/or height.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.XCursor
member.summary: A client which requests the X Cursor pseudo-encoding is declaring that it is capable of drawing a mouse cursor locally.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.RichCursor
member.summary: A client which requests the Cursor pseudo-encoding is declaring that it is capable of drawing a mouse cursor locally.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.PointerPox
member.summary: A TightVnc-specific extension.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.LastRect
member.summary: A client which requests the LastRect pseudo-encoding is declaring that it does not need the exact number of rectangles in a FramebufferUpdate message. Instead, it will stop parsing when it reaches a LastRect rectangle.

member.name: F:RemoteViewing.Vnc.VncEncoding.DesktopSize
member.summary: A client which requests the DesktopSize pseudo-encoding is declaring that it is capable of coping with a change in the framebuffer width and/or height.
